posts.name: Kade Rabe
posts.cooked: anyone had the 5v rail on their RIO DIO ports just die, happened to us in playoffs at 10,000k lakes regional, probably after collision with a defense bot. we prolly wont pursue getting a replacement or anything with how soon the new robot controller will be coming, and also we found we could just use our VRM instead for just the power, just wondering if this is a common failure mode anyone else has encountered before.

posts.name: Aaron
posts.cooked:
10,000,000 lakes?

Anyways, are any of the status lights different? Are there any faults for the RIO on Driver Station?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FIRST is the best STEM program

posts.custom_user_title: FIRST is the best STEM program

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
This can happen if the 5v rail is shorted to ground or another source (like 12v).

The power source is not extremely fault tolerant, so many teams have seen metal shavings from drilling while installed on the bot, etc…cause this to occur.

Some have been lucky and cleaned their devices thoroughly resolving the issue.

Others have cleaned and cleaned but the source circuit is permanently damaged and they need to source 5v from somewhere else.

posts.name: Kade Rabe
posts.cooked: no different status lights, only issue with the RIO is the 5V.

posts.name: Kade Rabe
posts.cooked: we did have metal shavings at one point, we vacuumed them out. although you might be right even though the issue was delayed after that it could’ve maybe had delayed permanent damage?

somewhat unrelated to this issue but we’ve ran into a rio with something wrong with its 5v rail. We added some limit switches at our first comp and I plugged one wire into signal and one wire in to 5v. This physically shouldn’t work as there is an internal pull up resistor on the DIO. However, with this rio, it did work. And it continued to work till one of our practice fields where the rio gave an unrecoverable error that eventually changed to a power fault in debugging later.

What color is you power status light? Status Light Quick Reference — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

If its red, that means that you have a chip in the ports shorting it. If its green, its something else

posts.name: Issac Woo
posts.cooked: I also want to offer this: try unscrewing your roboRIO apart, carefully, and vacuuming and using isopropyl alcohol to clean up anything inside there as well. You’ll be surprised how much dust is in there!

posts.name: Harrison
posts.cooked: Something like that happened to us. Our RSL port just completely died randomly during competition. All the ports on the rio were covered with electrical tape, so nothing should have been able to get in and damage it.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked:
Jwal:

This can happen if the 5v rail is shorted to ground or another source (like 12v).

The power source is not extremely fault tolerant, so many teams have seen metal shavings from drilling while installed on the bot, etc…cause this to occur.

I’m curious what devices you work with that are more fault tolerant then the roboRIO (do they continue to operate a particular pin that has a direct short)? The fact that most time you can just clean out the debris, and it doesn’t let out the magic smoke to me means it’s more fault tolerant then most devices.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
Off-highway vehicle controllers (consumer market, not industrial). It’s different requirements - although the design is of the same vintage as the roboRIO.

Every I/O is individually short-to-high, short-to-ground fault tolerant including external 5v sources short-to-battery. And no, if a fault is detected typically the pin is returned to a neutral/off state considering the safety implications of the actions.

There are some corner conditions where you can short-to-high a pin and short-to-ground another pin putting a dead short across the intrinsic body diode of a output driver chip frying it, but that requires multiple simultaneous faults.

I have only heard tails of the metal shavings issues which in some…cases folks have successfully recovered from by cleaning.

I have experienced a few students short-to-battery taking out supply rails mostly.

Don’t get me wrong everything has requirements, design limits that if exceeded causes damage - and I was a student in the early cRio days. The roboRIO is an improvement in that respect, but I’m liking what I hear about the new '27 control system being 100% S2H, S2G pin tested. I think that level of electrical circuit design & validation is appropriate for the FIRST teaching environment.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
Did you know you can jump-start a medium-sized motor grader using an arc welder?

That kind of fault tolerant .

To OP: the RIO on my bench at home has a fried 5v rail. It’s the second one our team has created in the last four years. No amount of cleanout has fixed the issue.

One more year, then we’ll have different problems to complain about!

posts.name: evanperryg
posts.cooked:
10,000,000 lakes

Yknow, I had this friend in college who insisted Wisconsin has more lakes than Minnesota.

OP, there’s a good chance you have a short somewhere. Most (all?) of the 5V pins on a RIO come from the same internal rail, so you can’t just unplug a few things. Unplug everything from the RIO except for power, and see if you can measure 5V on it.

If you see 5V, something you plugged into the RIO is shorting it out. Don’t plug anything back in until you know what caused she short. RIOs are very resilient compared to, say, a motor controller, but they’re still fragile.

If you don’t see 5V with everything unplugged, replace the RIO and diagnose it outside of the robot. Before you put in a new RIO, check for shorts in the wiring that was plugged into the RIO - it’s possible a short in your wiring killed the RIO’s 5V rail, and you don’t want to kill another one.

Metal shavings are the usual culprit in this situation. The absolute worst thing you can do in this scenario is continue to use the RIO without fixing it. The concern is that metal shavings can move around elsewhere, and kill the RIO entirely. Once you check the rest of your wiring, swap the RIO, take the bad one apart, and vacuum it. For the sake of ESD safety, I’d avoid using brushes or cloths to clean it, unless there’s a ton of scunge in there and no other way to get it out.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
I may be mistaken…but if I remember 2yrs ago right opening up our Rio with a fried 5v bus from a short to battery…most of the board was conformal coated to a decent thickness.

I 100% agree to stop use and find the issue…but I wonder if metal shavings deeper would really be an issue at all.

I remember the conformal not covering in and around the I/O pins, but a few mm past the mechanical openings started conformal coat.

Or maybe I’m confusing it with another controller I’ve torn down recently, who knows.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
Everyone is surprised at the 32v jump start voltage levels for a 12v system, or charging system load dump transients!

Who knows what someone rigs up out in the field to try to get themselves home…I’ve heard of welders being used before but never seen it

posts.name: Dan Nichols
posts.cooked:
Jwal:

32v jump start voltage levels for a 12v system, or charging system load dump transients!

Quite to the dismay of automotive electronics engineers everywhere… And Brandon Hjelstrom.

On a separate note, I sure hope the new Mobile Robot Controller is like potted or something. I think the roboRIO is especially bad with the giant gaps in the plastic around the DIO, but I wonder if material sneaks through the small gaps around the other ports? We tape over everything and still get internal shorts. Perhaps our elevator is generating especially tiny particulate.

We already know it won’t have sealed industrial/automotive connectors which is a bit disappointing (no one really uses them in FIRST though), but at least if they use actual Molex SL connectors instead of a header strip, there isn’t as much of a gaping hole in the case.

I’m not sure why it’s only the RIO we ever have this issue with, maybe the conformal coating is too thin or something? We weren’t just getting the 5V short fault, it wasn’t even booting until we took it apart and blew it out.

posts.name: Kade Rabe
posts.cooked: we finally got back in the shop yesterday apparently there actually was a metal shaving we missed at comp, it was stuck in deep so we missed when we vacuumed that stuff out. used compressed air in the shop to blow it out, and the problem has been resolved.

posts.name: Michael Tucker
posts.cooked:
The robioRIO has internal overcurrent protection on the 5V DIO ports (1A) and also the 6V PWM ports (2.2A).

This is intentional so that metal shavings in either of these rails do not result in further damaged electronics in the case.

We tape our exposed openings to the greatest extent possible.

Between events, we also pull the rio and open the case to clean it of debris.

Turns out that even a well sealed rio will somehow acquire debris inside the case.
